Study in the rapidly developing field of biotechnology and learn about the business opportunities of bringing innovations to a commercial market.
This course will give you an in-depth understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms of biological systems and how these can be applied to innovations tackling some of the world’s most pressing challenges. You’ll combine your skills and expertise in biotechnology with business and enterprise skills, developing an entrepreneurial mindset that can be applied to real-life biotechnology concepts.
Whether it’s scaling up the production of an innovative new fuel source, or making wearable devices than can detect disease, entrepreneurship in biotechnology combines science and business, bringing potentially life-changing products to a commercial market. You'll also take a unit focussing on the wider challenges of global environmental sustainability, giving you the opportunity to develop and use skills in teaching, media and communication, or public engagement.

You’ll graduate with the specialist skills and knowledge desired by industry, ready for a career in research or roles outside of academia in bioscience, agriculture or environmental industries. You'll also be suited for careers in non-lab settings such as legal, educational or entrepreneurial roles. Our dedicated careers team is on hand to offer individual guidance and help you choose between employment and further study.

We also offer the course with the option to specialise in sustainable biotechnologies or healthcare technologies and we have an MSc in Molecular Biosciences with specialisms offered in microbiology, bioinformatics and medical biosciences.

You should expect to spend approximately 35 to 40 hours a week studying on your course. These hours consist of structured activities and independent learning.
You will experience a mix of in person teaching, that will take place on campus, and structured online learning delivered through the University’s virtual learning environment.
MSc programmes deliver taught unit/modules in the first and second semester, with the Summer dedicated to a dissertation. The second semester will have less structured learning as you will start to prepare for your dissertation. Both during the dissertation preparation and the dissertation, supervision will take place at times suitable to you and your supervisor.
Typically, you can expect to spend between 20 to 25  hours on structured learning activities per teaching week, of which approximately 60 to 80% will be in timetabled sessions on campus, and the remainder online. The hours of structured time are dependent on the optional units you decide to take, with more practical subjects normally having more structured time than more theoretical ones.
Timetabled sessions delivered in person on campus will be a mix of lectures, seminars, tutorials, and laboratories. Online activities may include following a recorded lecture, or other learning materials, or joining a timetabled live interactive session through Microsoft Teams or Zoom.
The remainder of your time outside these structured activities will be spent in independent learning which includes individual research, reading journal articles and books, working on individual and group projects, preparing coursework assignments, presentations, or revising for exams.
To support you in your studies you will be able to access, outside of timetabled learning, facilities on campus and in Bath such as study spaces, computers, and the Library.

[HEADING] On this page
If you have Home fee status and are starting your postgraduate course in 2025/26, you may be eligible to apply for a postgraduate loan from the UK government.
The loan you can apply for and the amount you can get depends on where you normally live and whether you're studying for a master's degree or PhD. Contact your relevant student loans awarding agency for more advice and support about loans you can apply for.
If you normally live in England you can apply for loans for postgraduate master’s courses and doctoral programmes.
If you are studying for a master's degree, you can borrow up to £12,858.
If you are studying for a PhD, you can borrow up to £30,301 if your course starts on or after 1 August 2025. You can borrow up to £29,390 if your course started between 1 August 2024 and 31 July 2025.
If you normally live in Northern Ireland, you can apply for a loan for postgraduate master's, postgraduate certificate and diploma level courses. You can't apply for a loan for doctoral study.
If you are studying for a master's degree, you can borrow up to £6,500.
If you normally live in Scotland, you can apply for a loan to study a postgraduate diploma or master’s course. You can't apply for a loan for doctoral study.
If you're studying for a master's degree, you can borrow up to £13,900.
If you normally live in Wales you can apply for loans for postgraduate master’s courses and doctoral programmes.
If you are studying for a master's degree, you can borrow up to £19,255.
If you are studying for a PhD, you can borrow up to £29,130 if your course starts between 1 August 2025 and 31 July 2026. You can borrow up to £28,655 if your course starts between 1 August 2024 and 31 July 2025.
You should check the eligibility requirements from your student loans awarding agency to make sure you are able to apply for a loan.
You might not be eligible to apply if you:
Please note, eligibility requirements may vary between schemes and you should contact your relevant student loans awarding agency for further information.
• already have a qualification higher than or equivalent to the one you're applying for
• are already getting payments for another course
• have received a postgraduate master's loan before
• are behind in your repayments for a previous student loan
• already have Research Council funding
• already have a social work bursary
• are eligible for an NHS bursary
• are already getting an Educational Psychology bursary and your course starts on or after 1 August 2020
• are already getting payments for another course
• have received a postgraduate doctoral loan before
• already have a doctoral degree or a qualification that’s equivalent or higher
• are receiving a doctorate by publication
• are behind in your repayments for a previous student loan

[HEADING] On this page
If you apply to study at the University of Bath and your first language is not English, you will need to meet the minimum English language requirements before you can start your course.
If you need a Student visa to study in the UK, you will need to meet the UK Home Office requirements. You will not need to provide an English language test result if you are a national of one of the UK Visas and Immigration (UKVI) recognised majority English-speaking countries and have been permanently domiciled in the country.
You are welcome to apply before taking an English language test. If you are made an offer, it will be conditional upon you providing evidence that you have met the English language requirements for your course. You can find out what the requirements are on the relevant course page.
We accept various English language tests for the majority of our postgraduate taught courses. The tables below show the equivalent grades for each test.
You must have passed your English language test no more than 24 months before the start date of your course.
If you defer your offer, you will need to make sure that your English language test results are still valid for the start of your course.
** For the MA Contemporary European Studies (Euromasters) and MA Contemporary European Studies with Transatlantic Track (Euromasters), we are only able to accept an IELTS or TOEFL test result.
For tests taken after 1 July 2024, you must also achieve an Integrated Production Subscore of at least 100.
*We are not able to accept the Duolingo test for entry onto the MA Contemporary European Studies (Euromasters), MA Contemporary European Studies with Transatlantic Track (Euromasters), MA in Interpreting and Translating, MA Translation with Business Interpreting (Chinese) and MA Translation and Professional Language Skills courses.
If you have studied at a level equivalent to a UK Bachelor's, Master's, or PhD degree for at least 12 months in a UKVI recognised majority English-speaking country, you may be exempt from providing an English language test if your degree was awarded no more than 2 years prior to the intended date of admission.
Nationals of Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa, Uganda, and India may be exempt if your degree was awarded no more than 5 years prior to the intended date of admission.
Please contact your Admissions team to discuss.
If, as part of your application, you have provided an English language test result that does not meet the requirements of your chosen postgraduate course, you will not be exempt. You will instead need to provide an English language test result that meets the entry requirements of your course.
If you are a national of India and you have studied at a level equivalent to a UK Bachelor’s, Master’s, or PhD degree for at least 12 months at an institution in India where the medium of instruction was English, you may be exempt from providing an English language test if your degree was awarded no more than 5 years prior to the intended date of admission.
You will need to provide an official document from your awarding university confirming that the medium of instruction is English (e.g., your transcript, your degree certificate, an academic reference, or a statement of comparability from ENIC).
You will also need to provide evidence that you have reached the required level of Core English in your Indian 12th Standard examinations, as shown in the table below.
If, as part of your application, you have provided an English language test result that does not meet the requirements of your chosen postgraduate course, we will not be able to accept your Indian 12th standard examinations result and confirmation you have studied at a university where the medium of instruction is English. You will instead need to provide an English language test result that meets the entry requirements of your course.
If you have studied in a UKVI recognised majority English-speaking country, please refer to the guidance in the Degree from a majority English speaking country section above.
If you are a national of Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa, or Uganda and you have studied at a level equivalent to a UK Bachelor’s, Master’s, or PhD degree for at least 12 months at an institution in one of these countries where the medium of instruction was English, you may be exempt from providing an English language test if your degree was awarded no more than 5 years prior to the intended date of admission.
Applicants who need to improve their English language skills may be able to attend a pre-sessional programme at the University of Bath. We provide 5 or 10 week courses that will help you improve your English and academic skills to be ready to start your studies at Bath.
